awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   Mitochondrial Epistasis in Yeast
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how interactions among mitochondrial genes influence mitochondrial function and evolution. Mitochondria produce much of the energy used by cells, and this production depends upon precise interactions of multiple genes. Currently, interactions among mitochondrial genes have not been demonstrated, mainly because these genes are normally inherited as a single unit from the mother and such uniparental inheritance makes it difficult to study gene interactions. To get around this challenge, the researchers will study baker's yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae), which inherit mitochondrial DNA from both parents. They will first generate unique combinations of mitochondrial genes from a large yeast population to evaluate how these influence energy production. Then they will sequence single mitochondrial genomes to identify the specific genes involved. The project will advance our understanding of the mechanics of mitochondrial protein interactions and how they shape evolution. Additionally, the research will be integrated into a genetics laboratory course and engage 128 undergraduate students in hands-on research.

Respiratory function relies on compatible interactions between nuclear and mitochondrial genes, which leads to mitochondrial-nuclear epistasis and, theoretically, interactions between mitochondrial genes (mt-mt epistasis). Natural variation in mtDNAs contributes to differences in fitness, but because mtDNAs are typically uniparentally inherited and do not recombine, it is difficult to functionally dissect individual vs. epistatic effects of mtDNA polymorphisms. The yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae has bi-parental inheritance and recombination of mtDNAs. The natural distribution of mt-mt epistasis will be assessed by mating strains with identical nuclear genotypes but divergent mtDNAs, and the resulting strains containing mitochondrial recombinants will be functionally screened for evidence of mt-mt epistasis. Individual mitochondrial recombinant genomes will be sequenced and interacting loci mapped by comparing differences in allele pair frequencies between phenotypically distinct groups. This research will determine the role mt-mt epistasis plays in natural populations and provide information on mitochondrial recombination in yeast at the resolution of individual recombinant mtDNA haplotypes.

por.por_cntn:
Adaptation to novel environments, particularly new climatic zones, can be influenced by genetic variation in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). Understanding how mtDNAs contribute to adaptive processes is important for predicting how species will evolve to new environments and for increasing our knowledge of the forces that shape mtDNA evolution. It is challenging to determine which mitochondrial loci are important for adaptation because mtDNAs are typically inherited as single units from one parent without the recombination that normally shuffles genes to expose the effects of genetic variation. The research allowed by this Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant levered the power of mitochondrial recombination in a yeast model system to determine how different mitochondrial loci contribute to fitness differences. 

            The authors previously identified yeast mtDNAs that allowed for growth at high temperatures. Here, the researchers crossed strains containing mtDNAs conferring low- and high-temperature growth, isolated hundreds of strains containing identical nuclear genomes and recombinant mtDNAs, and phenotyped these strains under a variety of conditions. By comparing the distributions of phenotypes, the researchers revealed that genetic variation in multiple mitochondrial genes contribute to phenotypic differences and that these genes interact with each other in ways that are non-additive. Also, the researchers found that these interacting mitochondrial genes were dependent on the nuclear background, revealing three-way (mitochondrial x mitochondrial x nuclear) interactions. Importantly, genetic combinations that existed in the parental mtDNAs offered higher fitness potential than those in the recombinant mtDNAs indicating that in nature, selection occurs for these interacting loci. Modeling and analyses of sequencing data from pooled samples of recombinant mtDNAs suggested that recombination rates may be lower than those previously reported, although signatures of recombination are widely observed in mtDNAs isolated from nature. This work indicates that selection for interacting mitochondrial loci helps to shape mtDNA evolution and provides new insight into evolutionary processes. It also adds to our understanding of the genetic basis behind complex traits. The scientific impact of this work is substantial.

            This DDIG also provided numerous training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate level biologists. The graduate-level co-PI led an important research project, developed international collaborations, presented research findings at national and regional conferences and at invited seminars, and gained substantial mentoring experience. This project enabled the success of the graduate co-PI that was recognized with a Provosts Award for Research Excellence and a nomination for a Distinguished Dissertation Award at Binghamton University. One undergraduate student used the work through this project as the foundation of an undergraduate honors thesis. The strain resources created by the graduate co-PI and the undergraduates that worked on this project are freely available, and are being integrated into an authentic research module for an undergraduate laboratory course at Binghamton University that engages hundreds of students with appropriate conduct of research, hypothesis formulation, data collection and analysis, and presentations.
